posts.post_content:
Dovescape + Guile + noncreature spell (played by anyone) = infinite doves  
  
1) Spell is cast  
2) Dovescape triggers, tokens are made  
3) Guile exiles the spell, the you choose to cast the spell  
4) Repeat steps 1-3 until infinite is achieved, then choose not to cast the exiled spell.  
  
Turn 7 combo seems kinda slow though, but still very satisfying and relatively easy to fit into a deck.
posts.html:
Dovescape + Guile + noncreature spell (played by anyone) = infinite doves

1) Spell is cast
2) Dovescape triggers, tokens are made
3) Guile exiles the spell, the you choose to cast the spell
4) Repeat steps 1-3 until infinite is achieved, then choose not to cast the exiled spell.

Turn 7 combo seems kinda slow though, but still very satisfying and relatively easy to fit into a deck.

posts.post_content: I use this in a deck with [Glorious Anthem](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glorious Anthem ) and [Eldrazi Monument](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Eldrazi Monument). Does pretty well. If I can get a [Soul Warden](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Soul Warden) early then play the Anthem, then [Raise the Alarm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Raise the Alarm), then Eldrazi, followed by the Dovescape. True this takes time, but I usually have a few counterspells handy to buy me a turn or two.

posts.post_content:
If anyone is wondering, [Isochron Scepter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Isochron Scepter) does not get through this. It can be considered, however, to be a flying [Raise the Alarm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Raise the Alarm) without card disadvantage every turn, and that's pretty good.  
  
So I still play the two together. I also play this with [Guile](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Guile), [Guardian Seraph](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Guardian Seraph) and [Blood Seeker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Blood Seeker). I have a friend who plays [Soul Warden](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Soul Warden)s, though, and that kind of hurts. Thankfully I pack a decent amount of removal.
posts.html:
If anyone is wondering, Isochron Scepter does not get through this. It can be considered, however, to be a flying Raise the Alarm without card disadvantage every turn, and that's pretty good.

So I still play the two together. I also play this with Guile, Guardian Seraph and Blood Seeker. I have a friend who plays Soul Wardens, though, and that kind of hurts. Thankfully I pack a decent amount of removal.

posts.post_content:
Awesome art,  
but this has \*got\* to be one of he most random card ideas **ever**:  
  
"Hey man... what if we made a spell that, like, countered spells and gave people birds in exchange?"  
  
"\*cough\* DUDE- that makes *perfect sense*! Call it Dovescape. Pass the Funyuns!"  
  
That [Guile](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Guile) combo is hilarious and one of the most absurd infinite combos in the game.  
Also, try casting an [Energy Field](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Energy Field) before Dovescape- you're practically immortal!  
  
But they really missed a chance to please everyone here:  
  
Crowscape.
posts.html:
Awesome art,
but this has *got* to be one of he most random card ideas ever:

"Hey man... what if we made a spell that, like, countered spells and gave people birds in exchange?"

"*cough* DUDE- that makes perfect sense! Call it Dovescape. Pass the Funyuns!"

That Guile combo is hilarious and one of the most absurd infinite combos in the game.
Also, try casting an Energy Field before Dovescape- you're practically immortal!

But they really missed a chance to please everyone here:

Crowscape.

posts.post_content: Part of what makes this so freaking good is the fact you can't [Erase](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Erase) or [Naturalize](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Naturalize) it. In fact, you can't Erase or Naturalize anything while this is on the field. Thankfully we have [War Priest of Thune](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=War Priest of Thune) and [Keening Apparition](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Keening Apparition) to keep Dovescape in check.
